text: thumb|170px|The SL angle is an indicator of dorsal intercalated segment instability deformity (DISI). The SL angle goes between:[https://books.google.com/books?id=f-EkBAAAQBAJ&pg;=PA75 Page 75] in: \- A line through the long axis of the scaphoid bone. \- A line perpendicular to the distal articular surface of the lunate bone. It should normally be 30°-60°. Dorsal intercalated segment instability (DISI) is a deformity of the wrist where the lunate angulates to the posterior side of the hand. ==Causes== The main causes of DISI are: *Wrist trauma, with or without a fracture **Scaphoid fracture: bony DISI **Distal radius fracture: compensatory DISI **Malunion of radius fracture: adaptive DISI *Scapholunate ligament instability: ligamentous DISI ==References== Category:Orthopedics
title: Dorsal intercalated segment instability
